choices.text: Intact myelin sheath appears blue with luxol blue stain
Demyelinated areas appear blue with luxol blue stain
Intact myelin sheath appears blue with trichome stain
Demyelinated areas appear blue with trichome stain

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presented with symptoms of optic neuritis, tremors and gait disturbances. MRI reveals demyelinating lesions in brain and spinal cord. Image of section of the brain of this patient as below. Which of the following statement is true regarding this?
questions.solution:
Patient's symptoms, MRI examination suggest that she is suffering from MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS. Stain which is used is luxol blue.

  • Luxol blue stain is a histological staining technique used to visualize myelin in the central nervous system (CNS). In multiple sclerosis (MS), Luxol blue stain is used to:
  1. Detect demyelination: Luxol blue stains myelin blue, allowing researchers to identify areas of demyelination, which is a hallmark of MS.
  2. Assess lesion severity: The extent of demyelination can be quantified using Luxol blue, helping to evaluate the severity of MS lesions.
  3. Study remyelination: Luxol blue can also detect remyelination, which is important for understanding MS pathology and monitoring treatment efficacy.

Option C and D: Trichrome stain, also known as Masson's trichrome stain, is a histological staining technique used to visualize collagen and other connective tissue elements.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1271.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presents with painful swelling in diaphysis of left femur which has been rapidly growing. Histopathological examination shows Homer wright rosettes. Which of the following fusion gene is likely to cause this tumor?
questions.solution:
According to patient's age, location of the tumor and presence of homer wright rosettes, leads to a diagnosis of EWING'S SARCOMA.

EWSR1 - FL1 fusion gene located on chromosome 11, which encodes EWS/FL1 protein binds to chromatin and dysregulates transcription leading to uncontrolled growth and abnormal differentiation causing Ewing's sarcoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: PML - RARA (Acute promyelocytic leukemia)

Option B: TMPRSS2 - ERG (Prostate cancer)

Option D: BCR - ABL1 (Chronic myeloid leukemia)

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1193.

questions.text: What is the characteristic crystal deposit found in gouty arthritis?
questions.solution:
Gout is a common inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals in joints and tissues due to hyperuricemia. It is characterized by sudden, severe attacks of pain, redness, warmth, and swelling in the affected joint, most often the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint (podagra).

The gold standard for diagnosis is detecting needle-shaped, negatively birefringent MSU crystals in synovial fluid under polarized light microscopy.

Option A: Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are seen in PSEUDOGOUT.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1204.

choices.text: Linear deposition of complement, bullous pemphigoid
Granular deposition of IgA, dermatitis herpitiformis
Linear deposition of complement, pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of painful oral ulcers and skin blisters. Physical examination reveals:

1. Flaccid blisters on the skin and mucous membranes
2. Oral mucosa shows erosions and ulcers
3. Skin lesions are more prominent on the trunk and extremities

Direct immunofluorescence shows:

Which of the following is True statement?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation with painful oral ulcers and skin blisters, along with the physical examination findings and direct immunofluoresence which shows fishnet pattern is consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disease characterized by flaccid blisters and mucous membrane involvement.

Option A: Bullous pemphigoid presents with tense bullae and immunofluorescence shows linear deposits of Ig G and C3 on dermo epidermal junction .

Option B: Dermatitis herpetiformis: It is associated with celiac disease and shows papillary tip microabscess. With Ig A.

Option C: Pemphigus vulgaris shows fishnet appearance on immunofluorescence.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1161.

questions.text: 46 year old man has noticed speech difficulties for 2 months. On physical examination: weakness on left side. MRI of brain: large, irregular mass in the right cerebral hemisphere that extends to corpus callosum. Stereotactic biopsy: serpiginous foci of palisading necrosis with hyperchromatic anaplastic cells. Which of the following neoplasm is most likely to present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A. The location in the cerebral hemisphere and presence of serpiginous foci of pallisading necrosis are characteristic of an aggressive tumor called glioblastoma multiforme.

  • These neoplasms can infiltrate widely within CNS, particularly along white matter tracts.
  • Prognosis is poor.

Option A: Medulloblastoma is a malignant small round cell tumour that is found in the cerebellum or dorsal brainstem. It is the most common malignant CNS tumour in children.

Option C: Anaplastic astrocytoma have readily detectable mitotic activity.

Option D: Metastasis are multiple and located in grey white junction.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER:1295.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents with:
1. Cafe-au-lait spots on her skin
2. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (multiple bone lesions)
3. Precocious puberty
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
McCune-Albright Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by:

Cafe-au-lait spots (skin pigmentation)

Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (multiple bone lesions)

Precocious puberty (early onset of puberty)

The syndrome is caused by a somatic mutation in the GNAS gene, leading to activation of the cAMP pathway.

Options A,C and D are incorrect.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1195.

questions.text: Which pathway is commonly dysregulated in Basal Cell Carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Basal Cell Carcinoma is a type of non-melanoma skin cancer that arises from the basal cells, which are located in the lowest part of the epidermis (the outer skin layer).

BCC is typically associated with mutations in the Hedgehog signaling pathway, a critical pathway that regulates embryonic development and tissue patterning.

A. PI3K/AKT: breast cancer, endometrial and prostate cancer

B. MAPK/ERK: colorectal cancer, ovarian, hepatocelluar carcinoma, breast cancer

D. Wnt/β-catenin: Gastric cancer, lung cancer etc.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1147.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with a solitary, firm nodule on his ear. Histopathological examination reveals:
Islands of basaloid cells fits like a jigsaw puzzle within the fibrous dermal matrix.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A cylindroma is a type of benign tumor that arises from the skin or mucous membranes.
  • Often appear as small, firm nodules or masses under the skin.
  • In some cases, cylindromas can become large and disfiguring, especially if they occur on the face or scalp.

Options B,C and D are incorrect .

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1144.

questions.text: Rosenthal fibers are commonly found in which type of astrocytoma?
questions.solution:
• Rosenthal fibers are abnormal intracellular inclusions found in certain types of brain tumors, particularly pilocytic astrocytomas.
  • Rosenthal fibers are composed of glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), vimentin, and other intermediate filaments. They appear as brightly eosinophilic (pink-staining) fibers or globules within the cytoplasm of tumor cells, typically in areas with high cellular density.
  • The presence of Rosenthal fibers is a diagnostic hallmark of pilocytic astrocytomas, which are generally slow-growing and benign brain tumors.
  • REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1296.

choices.text: Negri bodies in Purkinje cells of cerebellum

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is bitten by a dog and develops symptoms of rabies. Which of the following is the most likely finding on histopathological examination of the brain?
questions.solution:
• Negri bodies are characteristic inclusion bodies found in the cytoplasm of neurons infected with the rabies virus.
  • Negri bodies are:
    • Typically found in the pyramidal cells of hippocampus,and Purkinje cells of cerebellum.
    • Round or oval, eosinophilic (pink-staining) inclusions
    • 2-10 μm in diameter
    • Composed of viral nucleoprotein and other rabies virus components

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1266.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man visits the physician because of a slowly enlarging nodule on his right eyelid. On physical examination, there is a 0.3-cm pearly nodule on the upper eyelid near the lateral limbus of the right eye. The lesion is excised, but multiple frozen sections are made during the surgery to minimize the extent of the resection and preserve the eyelid. The microscopic appearance of the lesion shows basophilic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei embedded in mucinous matrix, peripheral island of tumor cells tends to be arranged in parallel alignment(palisading). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
D.Basal cell carcinomas arise as pearly papules on sun-exposed areas of the skin, particularly the face.

  • They slowly infiltrate surrounding tissues, gradually enlarging. Although it rarely metastasizes.
  • Basal cell carcinoma can have serious local effects, particularly in the area of the eye.
  • Histological features of basaloid cells, mucinous matric and palisading arrangement are characteristic features of basal cell carcinoma.

Option A: Melanomas are usually pigmented, and they are composed of polygonal or spindle cells that tend to grow in sheets and infiltrate to produce a grossly irregular border to the lesion.

Option B: A dermatofibroma is a benign lesion of the dermis composed of cells resembling fibroblasts.

Option C: An actinic keratosis is a premalignant lesion of the epidermis that does not invade surrounding tissue.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1147.

choices.text: Granular IgA deposits in tips of dermal papillae
Linear deposition of Complement along the dermo-epidermal junction
IgM deposits in the papillary dermis

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with Pruritic, vesiculopapular rash on elbows and knees which is intensely itchy and associated with gluten sensitivity. Immunofluorescence microscopy in this patient typically reveals:
questions.solution:
Dermatitis herpetiformis is characterized by pruritic, vesiculopapular rash and association with gluten sensitivity.

Immunofluorescence in case of dermatitis herpetiformis shows Granular IgA deposits in tips of dermal papillae.

Option B: IgG deposits in the epidermis: More typical of pemphigus vulgaris.

Option C: Linear deposition of Complement along the dermo-epidermal junction: More typical of bullous pemphigoid.

Option D: IgM deposits in the papillary dermis: Not typically seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1193.

questions.text: A bone tumor has "Sun-ray" appearance on radiograph. Microscopy reveals malignant tumor cells with spindle cell morphology producing osteoid bone which is fine and lacelike. Abundant abnormal mitoses and extensive necrosis present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
"Sun-ray" appearance on radiograph: This refers to a characteristic radiographic pattern seen in osteosarcoma, where the periosteal reaction forms a pattern resembling sun rays. This is due to the tumor's aggressive growth and bone destruction.

Spindle cell morphology: Osteosarcoma typically consists of spindle-shaped cells with atypical mitoses and osteoid production with fine and lace like pattern.

B. Ewing's sarcoma: Typically has a "moth-eaten" appearance on radiograph and consists of small, round, blue cells.

C. Chondrosarcoma: Typically has a "rings and arcs" calcification pattern on radiograph and consists of cartilaginous matrix and binucleate cells.

D. Fibrosarcoma: Typically has a more benign appearance on radiograph and consists of fibroblasts with a storiform pattern.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1188.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with Fever, Headache, Stiff neck. CSF analysis: 1000 WBC/μL (90% neutrophils). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms (fever, headache, stiff neck) suggest The CSF analysis provides crucial information:
  • High WBC count (1000/μL): Indicates significant inflammation.
  • Neutrophil predominance (90%): Suggests bacterial infection.

A. Bacterial meningitis typically presents with acute onset of symptoms.

  • High CSF WBC count with neutrophil predominance is characteristic.
  • Common bacterial pathogens include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae.

B. Viral meningitis:

  • Typically has lower CSF WBC count (< 500/μL).
  • Lymphocytes predominate (not neutrophils).
  • Common viral pathogens include enteroviruses, herpesviruses, and arboviruses.

C. Tuberculous meningitis:

  • Typically has chronic or subacute presentation.
  • CSF analysis shows lymphocytic predominance.
  • Acid-fast bacilli are present on CSF smear or culture.

D. Fungal meningitis:

  • Typically occurs in immunocompromised patients.
  • CSF analysis shows lymphocytic or eosinophilic predominance.
  • Fungal culture or PCR is necessary for diagnosis.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1262.

questions.text: Microscopy of a pediatric CNS tumor has small blue cells, Homer-Wright rosettes which shows CD99 positivity. What is the most common location of this tumor?
questions.solution:
• Medulloblastoma is Primitive neuroectodermal tumor with small blue cells, Homer-Wright rosettes and CD99 positivity.
  • Medulloblastoma is a type of primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET) that originates from embryonal cells in the cerebellum.
  • The cerebellum is the most common location for medulloblastoma, accounting for approximately 70-80% of cases.

A. Cerebral cortex: While medulloblastoma can rarely occur in the cerebral cortex, it is not the most common location.

C. Brainstem: Brainstem gliomas are distinct from medulloblastoma.

D. Frontal lobe: Medulloblastoma is less likely to occur in the frontal lobe.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER. 1298.
